fields.description:
When an email fails to send, the user password is lost.

The password is left unencrypted and saved, hence next time the mail server is called to send an email, it tries to decrypt the already decrypted password leading to EncryptionExceptions
fields.summary: Encryption exceptions after a mail send failure

fields.description:
A post on Nabble Maven Users (http://www.nabble.com/core-api-container-outdated-on-snapshot-repository-tf2550173.html#a7110351) has given a brilliant idea for Bamboo.

For those who run on maven projects, It would be a great feature for successful nightly builds to automatically deploy to the remote repository. The build process would be something like this:

External:
(1) SVN/CVS commit new changes

Bamboo:
(2) Builds triggered, builds
(3) IF (successful build) && (maven II project) THEN run 'mvn deploy'

Some prerequisites for doing this are:
1. pom.xml must have distribution managment setup
2. bamboo server must have settings.xml setup with authentication settings.

I'm sure the guys at cargo codehaus would love you for this ;)
fields.summary: Automate deploying for all Maven II Projects once build is successful

fields.description:
Don't know how big a deal this is for you guys so i dropped the priority for you.

I recently moved a project over from beetlejuice (manually - starting to enjoy this xml hackery malarky) while the source was building. Thus everything copied over bar the latest builds entry in the projects.xml file.

When you visit that build version, it obviously shows a big yellow and blue screen with an error. This is fine, I believe you fixed this for another bug I raised a while back. However, on the main project summary screen, the message (where it would say latests build succeeded/failed) says no builds  are available yet and has a building logo. It should say the latest build details can't be found, though the likelihood of it getting into this situation when you actually release and upgrader will hopefully be unlikely....
fields.summary: incorrect status message on project summary if entry missing...

fields.description:
Something that was really useful in beetlejuice that has since been removed was the left hand sidebar which displayed all the builds and their current status (with link to the latest build).

It would be nice if you could see the current status of all the builds in bamboo from any page excluding the admin pages. for example, if i have just updated the config, it keeps me in the config screen, and I then have to return to the home page to see if the build has restarted or is still running.
fields.summary: Current build status always available

fields.description: If you try to clear the list of build dependencies in the build configuration you are greeted with ye olde servlet error page. (NullPointerException from logs, looks like an ArrayList is null when the form is not populated with anything)

fields.description: It would be a great advantage of Bamboo to be able to retrieve an artifact from a project build (specifically JAR files), to be included in the classpath of other dependent projects.  Many development shops maintain a "common" library of code that is reused between different projects and even development teams.  This concept is not supported in most CI environments.  What I would recommend would be a way to import dependencies from artifacts.  These dependencies may or may not trigger a build of the parent project to produce the artifacts, depending on the configuration.  These artifacts could simply be referenced in the Ant script with the -lib option.
fields.summary: Retrieve artifacts for inclusion in dependent projects

fields.description:
Currently build numbers over 1000 in IM messages use commas in the build numbers. This looks a bit silly:

> Confluence build 1,002 has FAILED (4 tests failed, no failures were new) : Change made by jschumacher

It would look better with a NumberFormat of "#", which would look like this:

> Confluence build 1002 has FAILED (4 tests failed, no failures were new). Change made by jschumacher.

(With punctuation fixed as well. ;))
fields.summary: Use NumberFormat "#" for build numbers in instant messages

fields.description:
We currently have a team of 7, 3 testers and 4 developers. We are polling every 3 hours for builds to the test server. What would be nice is to be able to specify specific polling times, for example 6am ,9am, 12pm, 3pm, 6pm and 9pm. 

This means that when the testers see an issue resolved in JIRA they would be able to predict when they will be seeing that fix on the test server.

I realise that with notifications they can also do this, but there is a subtle difference in they can structure their day around a predictable schedule rather than having to work out - ok last build was at 10.17am, so the next one is going to be at around 1.17pm.
fields.summary: Poll at specific times

fields.description:
The 'Builder Configuration' screen looks for 
* ./webapp/templates/plugins/builder/antBuilderedit.ftl
which is bundled in the distribution as
* ./webapp/templates/plugins/builder/antBuilderEdit.ftl

I suspect there may be other cases. Incidentally, having been bitten by this kind of thing many, many times over the years, our internal dev policy is to only use lowercase for filenames.

The workaround is to rename the file.

fields.description: Bamboo could provide a mechanism for collecting and displaying arbitrary metrics from each build. After a build has completed Bamboo should run a metrics step that would run selected analysis methods. The analysis system should be extensible so that custom or third party analysis tools could be integrated easily. Common analyzable metrics might include code complexity numbers, unit test coverage, performance numbers from daily builds etc. After collecting metrics for a build they could be plotted as a graph on the build summary screen to better illustrate the direction where the codebase has evolved across builds.
fields.summary: Extensible system for collecting project metrics across builds

fields.description: When I stop a build that is in the queue, the build results return as a red colour. For me, red kinda represents tests have failed. Should there be another colour for build intervention (such as compiling issues, downloading issues and so forth)?
fields.summary: Build shows up as red when 'Delete build from queue' is clicked. Needs more netural colouring

fields.description:
When I create a build using Perforce for source control, it works fine immediately afterward. I can even build multiple times. But once I restart Bamboo, I get startup errors referring to Perforce, as well as messages in the error log:

Strack Trace

java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.perforce.PerforceRepository.getSourceCodeDirectory(PerforceRepository.java:108)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.DefaultBuildChangeDetector.checkIfBuildNeedsBuilding(DefaultBuildChangeDetector.java:140)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.DefaultBuildChangeDetector.doTask(DefaultBuildChangeDetector.java:100)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.DefaultBuildChangeDetector.run(DefaultBuildChangeDetector.java:68)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Unknown Source)


If I then create a new build it will build, but then once Bamboo is restarted, both projects will fail from the get-go.

I've attached a clean logfile that includes starting the server for the first time, creating a build, building it twice, stopping the build, then trying to build the same build again with no changes to any configuration.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Perforce provider stops working after Bamboo restart

fields.description:
Bamboo has been reporting numerous "Unknown" changes lately, with the message "Could not get a change log for this change", as in BAM-2.

I suspect this is due to problems with contacting the CVS repository.  Whatever the reason, I was wondering whether Bamboo could try to generate the changelog again, after it fails.

Either
* When a user specifically asks it to
* Whenever it displays the changelog
* Periodically.  Eg there could be some regular task to go and fill in any unknown change logs.
fields.summary: Could missing change logs be generated later?

fields.description:
Unlike with the CVS modules, creating an SVN build will use a random (or SVN - not sure which) id as the checkout folder. Normally this wouldn't be an issue, but when debugging or cleaning up, it's not useful.

It would be more preferable if it were to use the project id or name as the checkout folder, as clearly unlike cvs you don't specify a module name for svn. This is set in the <myWorkingDirectorySubDirectory>[MODULE NAME]</myWorkingDirectorySubDirectory> tag.
fields.summary: SVN Checkout folder name unreadable

fields.description: The current site title is 'The Bamboo Build System - Bamboo Continuous Integration Server'. Personally this is saying the same thing twice in two ways. I'd like to be able to manually set the second half to reflect what our use of that server is.
fields.summary: customise site title

fields.description: The default value for the base url is localhost. Being a webserver, this is obviously wrong. It would be better if it could use the webserver address rather than localhost.
fields.summary: default base url is invalid

fields.description:
Not sure how your average time thing works. Since I used the old beetlejuice files, I think it might be incorrect.

I've removed all 'failed' builds that marked themselves as successful.  Looking through every build in the results page, the shortest build I can find is 52 minutes, the longest being 1304. Yet the average time is 45 minutes.....

I'll restart the app tonight, then re-index - never got round to it before. Then check again and see if this changes, but I can't see why it would, Also, the rss allbuilds.xml and failedbuilds.xml don't include the beetlejuice builds, but may still contain the deleted builds that were marked as successful even though they weren't.

any obvious ideas why this would be the case? I can manually calculate it to see, but if the minimum successful build is 52 I don't see how it could drop an average of 45...
fields.summary: build timer incorrect

fields.description:
A team I know have a south park character for each team member.  This is displayed on the page when they break the build .

It's sounds frivolous, but had a major impact on how the team responded to broken builds (previously they ignored them).  They have open sourced it http://sourceforge.net/projects/build-o-matic.  I would really like something similar in Bamboo
fields.summary: Add photo (or fun team image) to the user, display this when they break the build

fields.description:
I'd like to be able to use a different filter for the number of builds displayed on the project summary page and results page.

I'd like to see all builds on the summary page because the are grouped and do not take long to display, and it's a nice coverage of build history. However I don't want to see them all individually on the results page as after 800 it takes forever to load the page - I'd personally keep this down to 30 or 60 days max.

fields.description:
I am evaluating CI tools which may serve us as alternatives to CruiseControl.

We are a quite advanced user of CI tools. I am looking at Bamboo, Team City and the other existing ones. With Team City and Bamboo, they are obviously new products and their feature sets are uncertain.

We would be more inclined to take the plunge with Bamboo if we knew where it was heading. One of the best feature matrixes I have seen is the on the DamageControl guys have done. See http://docs.codehaus.org/display/DAMAGECONTROL/Continuous+Integration+Server+Feature+Matrix.

I would love to see where you are heading expressed in something similar. Or failing that, any sort of roadmap at all.

I am downloading each of the alphas and playing with them, but at some point we need to determine whether to try and use it for real.
fields.summary: Would like to see a feature list along the lines of http://docs.codehaus.org/display/DAMAGECONTROL/Continuous+Integration+Server+Feature+Matrix

fields.description: As this feature seems to be more difficult to build in later I figured I would throw in remote build support.  We like to use a build farm due to the size of our codebase and the number of active development branches.  Also the ability the test suites on different VMs provides some level of comfort.  As Pulse and TeamCity have this capability this is becoming one of our baseline requirements though other customers may see this differently.
fields.summary: Ability to do remote/distributed builds

fields.description:
If you have a build that is disabled, and you try to "checkout & build build", then nothing happens.  While it is reasonable that "checkout & build build" doesn't work when the build is disabled I think the current behaviour is very unfriendly.

Really, I'd like to be able to trigger a build manually even if automatic building is disabled,
However, there should otherwise be a message saying that the build will not happen because the build is disabled.

Maybe if having the build disabled is meant to stop the user manually triggering a build, then the "c & b b" button should be disabled too.  (I actually like giving error messages better than disabling controls, because it can be difficult for a user to ascertain why a control is disabled, but on the other hand it is a bit mean to provide a button that won't work, because the user doesn't realise it won't work until they press it. )
fields.summary: Disabled build should also hide the build option

fields.description: This may just get categorised as a build artifact but the tighter the integration with a static analysis tool - which we use as a code review/code smell tool would be beneficial.  Though my preference is the inspections bundled with Intellij I also use findBugs.  The ability to schedule different profiles and alert/alarm for anything findBugs categorizes as high would be valuable.  Realizing these artificats more directly in the UI rather than as files would be a differentiator for me.
fields.summary: Easy integration with static analysis tools

fields.description: It should give an example so there's no confusion if it's bamboo.home or BAMBOO_HOME.

not really sure what's going on, but for some reason the whole triggering from an ip address of the cvs box seems to have stopped working, possibly since moving over to 0.4 but can't be sure. Just doesn't work on bamboo. Definately still works on our other beetlejuice box so it's not the server having had the facility removed. Thus we don't get the blame emails as we have to do manual triggers. 

Initially booting the app polls for changes and build if there are any, just subsequent changes are not seen.

One of the primary reasons for selecting Bamboo over Zutubi's Pulse or Jetbrains TeamCity would be the potential for tight integration between the build server both Jira and Confluence.  As a start it would be nice to see what Jira issues were included in each build.

I could continue on the theme and say it would be nice to publish artifacts in Confluence either autmoted with each build or as a designated push especially around release time.

fields.description:
From http://forums.atlassian.com/message.jspa?messageID=257234648#257234648


Hi,
It looks as if there's an installation name issue...

I first installed the Windows standalone, specifing my own root of D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo but keeping the default suffix of _0.4. I also specified an alternative BambooHome outside the app directory.

When I came to run it, I found that nothing happened, so I downloaded the .zip version, unzipped that to \Bamboo, set the BambooHome (in fact, copied it from the previous install) and run that, whereupon it ran up correctly.

I compared the two trees and was surprised to see that apart from the .install4j folder (surely not needed in the .zip archive?) they were identical, and was even more surprised to see the following behaviour!

{noformat}
D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo_0.4>start-bamboo.bat
Press any key to continue . . .
D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo_0.4>cd ..

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>mv Bamboo_0.4 Bamboo04

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>cd Bamboo04

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo04>start-bamboo.bat
2006-09-28 09:44:41,946 INFO [main] [HttpServer] Version Jetty/5.1.4
2006-09-28 09:44:41,977 INFO [main] [Credential] Checking Resource aliases
2006-09-28 09:44:42,587 INFO [main] [Container] Started org.mortbay.jetty.servlet.WebApplicationHandler@1abab88
Terminate batch job (Y/N)? y

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo04>cd ..

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>mv Bamboo04 Bamboo_0.4

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>cd Bamboo_0.4

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo_0.4>start-bamboo.bat
Press any key to continue . . .
D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo_0.4>cd ..

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>mv Bamboo_0.4 Bamboo04

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>cd Bamboo04

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo04>start-bamboo.bat
2006-09-28 09:46:04,916 INFO [main] [HttpServer] Version Jetty/5.1.4
2006-09-28 09:46:04,956 INFO [main] [Credential] Checking Resource aliases
Terminate batch job (Y/N)? y

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo04>
{noformat}

Just to continue, Bamboo_04 & Bamboo0.4 are OK, but not Bamboo_0.4 !

/Gwyn
